articles.title: This tiny laser could transform how we see and sense the world
articles.summary: Researchers from NTNU and EPFL have unveiled a compact, low-cost laser that outperforms current models in speed, control, and precision. Built using microchip technology, it can be mass-produced for use in everything from Lidar navigation to gas detection. The design’s stability and easy frequency tuning could transform communication and sensing technologies.
articles.content:
Laser technology plays a vital role in modern life, supporting everything from precise scientific measurements to advanced communication systems. It underpins technologies such as self-driving vehicles, high-speed fiber optic networks, and even tools that detect gases in the atmosphere.

A research team led by Associate Professor Johann Riemensberger from the Department of Electronic Systems at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU) has developed a new kind of laser designed to overcome several challenges found in existing models.

"Our results can give us a new type of laser that is both fast, relatively cheap, powerful and easy to use," says Riemensberger.

The team's findings have been published in Nature Photonics. The project is a collaboration between NTNU, the Swiss École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), and Luxtelligence SA.

Self-driving cars and air quality detectors

Traditional precision lasers are often bulky, costly, and tricky to fine-tune.

"Our new laser solves several of these problems," says Riemensberger.

This improvement could make the technology especially useful in self-driving cars, which rely on a technique known as Lidar to map their surroundings. Lidar works by measuring how long it takes light from a laser to bounce back, or by detecting tiny changes in the light's wave phase. The new laser can perform such measurements with remarkable accuracy -- within about four centimeters.

The researchers also demonstrated that their laser can effectively detect hydrogen cyanide gas in the air, a substance commonly referred to as "hydrocyanic acid." Because this compound is extremely toxic even in small amounts, being able to identify it quickly is essential for safety and environmental monitoring.

Advanced materials, microsized light circuits

The researchers created the new laser with advanced materials and microscopic light circuits.

The laser emits a powerful and stable beam of light. Also, among the advantages is that users can easily adjust the frequency quickly and smoothly, without sudden jumps.

"You can also easily control it with just one control instead of many," Riemensberger points out.

The laser is built using chip technology that is already available. This makes it possible to mass-produce it cheaply.

"Our findings make it possible to create small, inexpensive and user-friendly measuring instruments and communication tools with high performance," Riemensberger said.

The work was a collaboration between EPFL (experiments), Luxtelligence SA (chip production) and NTNU (design and simulations). It started when Riemensberger was still a postdoctoral fellow at EPFL. The collaboration continues through an EIC Pathfinder OPEN scholarship called ELLIPTIC.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant technological breakthrough: a compact, low-cost laser with superior speed, control, and precision that can be mass-produced using existing microchip technology. This innovation has broad real-world applications including enhancing self-driving car Lidar systems and improving toxic gas detection, which can benefit public safety and environmental monitoring. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a collaborative scientific achievement with tangible societal benefits.
articles.personality_title: New tiny laser promises better sensing for cars and safety
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Lasers are important tools used in many technologies like self-driving cars and gas detectors. However, many lasers today are large, expensive, and hard to adjust.

**What happened** – Researchers from the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU) and the Swiss École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL) created a small, low-cost laser chip. This new laser is faster, more precise, and easier to control than current lasers. It can measure distances with about four centimeters accuracy and detect dangerous gases like hydrogen cyanide.

**Impact** – This laser can improve Lidar systems in self-driving cars, helping them better understand their surroundings. It can also help quickly find toxic gases, protecting people and the environment. Because it uses common chip technology, it can be made cheaply and in large amounts.

**What’s next step** – The team will continue working on the laser through a research program called ELLIPTIC. They aim to develop small, easy-to-use devices for measuring and communication that use this laser technology.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new tiny laser chip from NTNU and EPFL offers faster, cheaper, and more precise sensing for safer cars and better gas detection.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouveau laser miniature promet de meilleures détections pour voitures et sécurité
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les lasers sont des outils importants utilisés dans de nombreuses technologies comme les voitures autonomes et les détecteurs de gaz. Cependant, beaucoup de lasers actuels sont gros, coûteux et difficiles à régler.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université norvégienne de science et de technologie (NTNU) et de l’École polytechnique fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL) ont créé une puce laser petite et peu coûteuse. Ce nouveau laser est plus rapide, plus précis et plus facile à contrôler que les lasers actuels. Il peut mesurer des distances avec une précision d’environ quatre centimètres et détecter des gaz dangereux comme le cyanure d’hydrogène.

**Impact** – Ce laser peut améliorer les systèmes Lidar des voitures autonomes, les aidant à mieux comprendre leur environnement. Il peut aussi aider à détecter rapidement des gaz toxiques, protégeant ainsi les personnes et l’environnement. Comme il utilise une technologie de puce commune, il peut être fabriqué en grande quantité et à moindre coût.

**Prochaines étapes** – L’équipe continuera à travailler sur ce laser dans le cadre d’un programme de recherche appelé ELLIPTIC. Ils veulent développer de petits appareils faciles à utiliser pour la mesure et la communication utilisant cette technologie laser.

**Phrase clé** – Une nouvelle puce laser miniature de NTNU et EPFL offre une détection plus rapide, moins chère et plus précise pour des voitures plus sûres et une meilleure détection des gaz.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo láser diminuto mejora la detección para autos y seguridad
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los láseres son herramientas importantes usadas en muchas tecnologías como autos autónomos y detectores de gases. Sin embargo, muchos láseres actuales son grandes, caros y difíciles de ajustar.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad Noruega de Ciencia y Tecnología (NTNU) y de la Escuela Politécnica Federal de Lausana (EPFL) crearon un láser pequeño y de bajo costo en forma de chip. Este nuevo láser es más rápido, preciso y fácil de controlar que los láseres actuales. Puede medir distancias con una precisión de unos cuatro centímetros y detectar gases peligrosos como el cianuro de hidrógeno.

**Impacto** – Este láser puede mejorar los sistemas Lidar de los autos autónomos, ayudándolos a entender mejor su entorno. También puede ayudar a detectar rápidamente gases tóxicos, protegiendo a las personas y al medio ambiente. Como usa tecnología común de chips, puede fabricarse barato y en grandes cantidades.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo continuará trabajando en este láser a través de un programa de investigación llamado ELLIPTIC. Quieren desarrollar dispositivos pequeños y fáciles de usar para medición y comunicación que usen esta tecnología láser.

**Frase clave** – Un nuevo chip láser diminuto de NTNU y EPFL ofrece una detección más rápida, barata y precisa para autos más seguros y mejor detección de gases.
